\subsubsection{accounts.views module}

Handles all activities associated with user accounts.

This module handles all of the functions relating to users such as creating
accounts, resetting passwords, searches. profiles etc.

\index{register() (in module accounts.views)@\spxentry{register()}\spxextra{in module accounts.views}}

User registration form

This form allows a user to register for the system. The form includes
Ajax code to look up the system number and pre\sphinxhyphen{}fill the first and last name.

This form also sends the email to the user to confirm the email address
is valid.

\index{scroll1() (in module dashboard.views)@\spxentry{scroll1()}\spxextra{in module dashboard.views}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{dashboard:dashboard.views.scroll1}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dashboard.views.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{scroll1}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{request}}}{}
Cutdown homepage to be called by infinite scroll.

This handles the right column \sphinxhyphen{} discussion posts

Infinite scroll will call this when the user scrolls off the bottom
of the page. We don’t need to update anything except the posts so exclude
other front page database hits.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{scroll2() (in module dashboard.views)@\spxentry{scroll2()}\spxextra{in module dashboard.views}}

Cutdown homepage to be called by infinite scroll.

This handles the left column \sphinxhyphen{} announcements

Infinite scroll will call this when the user scrolls off the bottom
of the page. We don’t need to update anything except the posts so exclude
other front page database hits.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{likepost\_set (forums.models.Post attribute)@\spxentry{likepost\_set}\spxextra{forums.models.Post attribute}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{forums:forums.models.Post.likepost_set}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{likepost\_set}}}
Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a
many\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}one relation.

In the example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{Child}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{Model}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{parent} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{ForeignKey}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{Parent}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{related\PYGZus{}name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{children}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Parent.children}} is a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ReverseManyToOneDescriptor}} instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager
class built by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{create\_forward\_many\_to\_many\_manager()}} defined below.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{objects (forums.models.Post attribute)@\spxentry{objects}\spxextra{forums.models.Post attribute}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{forums:forums.models.Post.objects}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{objects}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{ = \textless{}django.db.models.manager.Manager object\textgreater{}}}}
\end{fulllineitems}

\index{text (forums.models.Post attribute)@\spxentry{text}\spxextra{forums.models.Post attribute}}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\index{member (notifications.models.InAppNotification attribute)@\spxentry{member}\spxextra{notifications.models.InAppNotification attribute}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{notifications:notifications.models.InAppNotification.member}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{member}}}
Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a many\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}one or
one\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}one (via ForwardOneToOneDescriptor subclass) relation.

In the example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{Child}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{Model}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{parent} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{ForeignKey}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{Parent}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{related\PYGZus{}name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{children}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Child.parent}} is a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ForwardManyToOneDescriptor}} instance.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{member\_id (notifications.models.InAppNotification attribute)@\spxentry{member\_id}\spxextra{notifications.models.InAppNotification attribute}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{notifications:notifications.models.InAppNotification.member_id}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{member\_id}}}

\index{member (notifications.models.NotificationMapping attribute)@\spxentry{member}\spxextra{notifications.models.NotificationMapping attribute}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{notifications:notifications.models.NotificationMapping.member}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{member}}}
Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a many\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}one or
one\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}one (via ForwardOneToOneDescriptor subclass) relation.

In the example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{Child}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{Model}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{parent} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{ForeignKey}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{Parent}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{related\PYGZus{}name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{children}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Child.parent}} is a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ForwardManyToOneDescriptor}} instance.

\end{fulllineitems}

Get a list of all unacklowledged notifications for a user

Returns a list of notifications for the user where the status is
unacknowledged.

If the list is over 10 then the last item is a link to the notifications
page to view them all.

Called by Cobalt applications to tell notify they have done something.

Main entry point for general notifications of events within the system.
Applications publish an event through this call and Notifications tells
any member who has registered an interest in this event.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{application\_name}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} name of the calling app

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{event\_type}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} 

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{topic}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} specific to the application, high level event

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{subtopic}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} specific to the application, next level event

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{msg}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} a brief description of the event

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{link}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} an HTML relative link to the event (Optional)

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{html\_msg}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} a long description of the event (Optional)

\item {}

\end{itemize}

Nothing

\end{description}\end{quote}

\subsubsection{payments.core module}
\label{\detokenize{payments:module-payments.core}}\label{\detokenize{payments:payments-core-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!payments.core@\spxentry{payments.core}}\index{payments.core@\spxentry{payments.core}!module@\spxentry{module}}
Handles all activities associated with payments that do not talk to users.

This module handles all of the functions that do not interact directly with
a user. i.e. they do not generally accept a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Request}} and return an
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{HttpResponse}}. Arguably these could have been put directly into models.py
but it seems cleaner to store them here.

See also {\hyperref[\detokenize{payments:module-payments.views}]{\emph{Payments Views}}}. This handles the user side of the interactions.
They both work together.
\begin{description}
\item[{Key Points:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Payments is a service module, it is requested to do things on behalf of
another module and does not know why it is doing them.

\item {} 
Payments are often not real time, for manual payments, the user will
be taken to another screen that interacts directly with Stripe, and for
automatic top up payments, the top up may fail and require user input.

\item {} 
The asynchronous nature of payments makes it more complex than many of
the Cobalt modules so the documentation needs to be of a higher standard.
See \sphinxhref{./payments\_overview.html}{Payments Overview} for more details.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}
\index{auto\_topup\_member() (in module payments.core)@\spxentry{auto\_topup\_member()}\spxextra{in module payments.core}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{payments:payments.core.auto_topup_member}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{payments.core.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{auto\_topup\_member}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{member}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{topup\_required}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{payment\_type}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{\textquotesingle{}Auto Top Up\textquotesingle{}}}}{}
process an a member.

Internal function to handle a member needing to process an auto top up.
This function deals with successful top ups and failed top ups. For
failed top ups it will notify the user and disable auto topups. It is
the calling functions problem to handle the consequences of the non\sphinxhyphen{}payment.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}

\item {}

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{the payment is larger than the top up amount. e.g. balance is 25}}\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{,}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{if}}) \textendash{} 

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{up amount is 50}}\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{payment is 300.}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{top}}) \textendash{} 

\item {}

\index{callback\_router() (in module payments.core)@\spxentry{callback\_router()}\spxextra{in module payments.core}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{payments:payments.core.callback_router}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{payments.core.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{callback\_router}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{route\_code}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{route\_payload}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{tran}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{status}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{\textquotesingle{}Success\textquotesingle{}}}}{}
Central function to handle callbacks

Callbacks are an asynchronous way for us to let the calling application
know if a payment successed or not.

We could use a routing table for this but there will only ever be a small
number of callbacks in Cobalt so we are okay to hardcode it.

We should not get tran provided but do for early testing. This will be
removed later, but for now allows us to reverse the transaction for testing.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {}

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{} value to return to function}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{route\_payload}}) \textendash{} 

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{} for testing only. remove later}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{tran}}) \textendash{} 

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{} Success}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{status}}) \textendash{} 

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
Nothing

\end{description}\end{quote}

\index{payment\_api() (in module payments.core)@\spxentry{payment\_api()}\spxextra{in module payments.core}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{payments:payments.core.payment_api}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{payments.core.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{payment\_api}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{request}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{description}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{amount}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{member}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{route\_code}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{route\_payload}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{organisation}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{other\_member}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{log\_msg}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{payment\_type}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{url}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}}{}
API for payments from other parts of the application.

There is a user on the end of this who needs to know what is happening,
so we return a page that tells them. It could be:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{)}%
\item {} 
A payment page for one off payments

\item {} 
A failed auto payment message

\item {} 
A success page from auto topup

\item {} 
A success page because they had enough funds in the account

\end{enumerate}

The route\_code provides a callback and the route\_payload is the string
to return. For 3 and 4, the callback will be called before the page is
returned.

Payments should be the last step in the process for the calling application
as there is no way to return control to the application after payments is
done. Note: This would be possible if required.

amount is the amount to be deducted from the users account. A positive
amount is a charge, a negative amount is an incoming payment.

We accept either organisation as the counterpart for this payment or
other\_member. We must have either an organisation or a member, but
we can’t pay to both.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{} standard request object}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{request}}) \textendash{} 

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{} text description of the payment}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{description}}) \textendash{} 

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{} how much}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{amount}}) \textendash{} 

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{} User object related to the payment}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{member}}) \textendash{} 

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{} code to map to a callback}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{route\_code}}) \textendash{} 

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{} value to retirn on completion}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{route\_payload}}) \textendash{} 

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{} linked organisation}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{organisation}}) \textendash{} 

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{} User object}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{other\_member}}) \textendash{} 

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{} message for the log}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{log\_msg}}) \textendash{} 

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{} description of payment}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{payment\_type}}) \textendash{} 

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{} next url to go to}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{url}}) \textendash{} 

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
request \sphinxhyphen{} page for user

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{stripe\_auto\_payment\_intent() (in module payments.core)@\spxentry{stripe\_auto\_payment\_intent()}\spxextra{in module payments.core}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{payments:payments.core.stripe_auto_payment_intent}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{payments.core.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{stripe\_auto\_payment\_intent}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{request}}}{}
Called from the auto top up webpage.

This is very similar to the one off payment. It lets Stripe
know to expect a credit card and provides a token to confirm
which one it is.

When a user is going to set up a credit card we
tell Stripe and Stripe gets ready for it. By this point in the process
we have handed over control to the Stripe code which calls this function
over Ajax.

This functions expects a json payload as part of \sphinxtitleref{request}.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{} This needs to contain a Json payload.}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{request}}) \textendash{} 

\end{description}\end{quote}
\subsubsection*{Notes}

The Json should include:
data\{“stripe\_customer\_id”: This is the Stripe customer\_id in our table
for the customer that we are handling\}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\{‘publishableKey’:? ‘clientSecret’:?\}

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
json

\end{description}\end{quote}
\subsubsection*{Notes}

publishableKey = our Public Stripe key,
clientSecret = client secret from Stripe

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{stripe\_manual\_payment\_intent() (in module payments.core)@\spxentry{stripe\_manual\_payment\_intent()}\spxextra{in module payments.core}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{payments:payments.core.stripe_manual_payment_intent}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{payments.core.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{stripe\_manual\_payment\_intent}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{request}}}{}
Called from the checkout webpage.

When a user is going to pay with a credit card we
tell Stripe and Stripe gets ready for it. By this point in the process
we have handed over control to the Stripe code which calls this function
over Ajax.

This functions expects a json payload as part of \sphinxtitleref{request}.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{} This needs to contain a Json payload.}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{request}}) \textendash{} 

\end{description}\end{quote}
\subsubsection*{Notes}

The Json should include:
data\{“id”: This is the StripeTransaction in our table that we are handling
“amount”: The amount in the system currency\}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\{‘publishableKey’:? ‘clientSecret’:?\}

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
json

\end{description}\end{quote}
\subsubsection*{Notes}

publishableKey = our Public Stripe key,
clientSecret = client secret from Stripe

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{stripe\_webhook() (in module payments.core)@\spxentry{stripe\_webhook()}\spxextra{in module payments.core}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{payments:payments.core.stripe_webhook}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{payments.core.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{stripe\_webhook}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{request}}}{}
Callback from Stripe webhook

In development, Stripe sends us everything. In production we can configure
the events that we receive. This is the only way for Stripe to communicate
with us.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
Stripe sends us multiple similar things, for example \sphinxstyleemphasis{payment.intent.succeeded}
will accompany anything that uses a payment intent. Be careful to only
handle one out of the multiple events.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

For \sphinxstylestrong{manual payments} we can receive:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
payment.intent.created \sphinxhyphen{} ignore

\item {} 
charge.succeeded \sphinxhyphen{} process

\item {} 
payment.intent.succeeded \sphinxhyphen{} ignore

\end{itemize}

For \sphinxstylestrong{automatic payment set up}, we get:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
customer.created \sphinxhyphen{} ignore

\item {} 
setup\_intent.created \sphinxhyphen{} ignore

\item {} 
payment\_method.attached \sphinxhyphen{} process

\item {} 
setup\_intent.succeeded \sphinxhyphen{} ignore

\end{itemize}

For \sphinxstylestrong{automatic payments} we get:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
payment\_intent.succeeded \sphinxhyphen{} ignore

\item {} 
payment\_intent.created \sphinxhyphen{} ignore

\item {} 
charge\_succeeded \sphinxhyphen{} ignore (we already know this from the API call)

\end{itemize}

\sphinxstylestrong{Meta data}

We use meta data to track what the event related to. This is added by us
when we call Stripe and returned to us by Stripe in the callback.

Fields used:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{cobalt\_tran\_type} \sphinxhyphen{} either \sphinxstyleemphasis{Manual} or \sphinxstyleemphasis{Auto} for manual and auto top up
transactions. If this is missing then the transaction is invalid.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{cobalt\_pay\_id} \sphinxhyphen{} for manual payments this is the linked transaction in
MemberTransaction.

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode

\index{test\_callback() (in module payments.core)@\spxentry{test\_callback()}\spxextra{in module payments.core}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{payments:payments.core.test_callback}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{payments.core.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{test\_callback}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{status}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{payload}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{tran}}}{}
Eventually I will be moved to another module. I am only here for testing purposes

I also shouldn’t have the 3rd parameter. I only get status and the payload that I provided
when I made the call to payments to get money from a member. I am responsible for my own
actions, but for testing I get the StripeTransaction passed so I can reverse it.

\index{save() (payments.models.MemberTransaction method)@\spxentry{save()}\spxextra{payments.models.MemberTransaction method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{payments:payments.models.MemberTransaction.save}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{save}}}{\emph{\DUrole{o}{*}\DUrole{n}{args}}, \emph{\DUrole{o}{**}\DUrole{n}{kwargs}}}{}
Save the current instance. Override this in a subclass if you want to
control the saving process.

The ‘force\_insert’ and ‘force\_update’ parameters can be used to insist
that the “save” must be an SQL insert or update (or equivalent for
non\sphinxhyphen{}SQL backends), respectively. Normally, they should not be set.

\end{fulllineitems}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Child.parent}} is a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ForwardManyToOneDescriptor}} instance.

\index{save() (payments.models.OrganisationTransaction method)@\spxentry{save()}\spxextra{payments.models.OrganisationTransaction method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{payments:payments.models.OrganisationTransaction.save}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{save}}}{\emph{\DUrole{o}{*}\DUrole{n}{args}}, \emph{\DUrole{o}{**}\DUrole{n}{kwargs}}}{}
Save the current instance. Override this in a subclass if you want to
control the saving process.

The ‘force\_insert’ and ‘force\_update’ parameters can be used to insist
that the “save” must be an SQL insert or update (or equivalent for
non\sphinxhyphen{}SQL backends), respectively. Normally, they should not be set.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{StripeTransaction (class in payments.models)@\spxentry{StripeTransaction}\spxextra{class in payments.models}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{payments:payments.models.StripeTransaction}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{payments.models.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{StripeTransaction}}}{\emph{\DUrole{o}{*}\DUrole{n}{args}}, \emph{\DUrole{o}{**}\DUrole{n}{kwargs}}}{}

Only stores basic information, for the full details use the

\index{membertransaction\_set (payments.models.StripeTransaction attribute)@\spxentry{membertransaction\_set}\spxextra{payments.models.StripeTransaction attribute}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{payments:payments.models.StripeTransaction.membertransaction_set}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{membertransaction\_set}}}
Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a
many\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}one relation.

In the example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{Child}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{Model}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{parent} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{ForeignKey}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{Parent}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{related\PYGZus{}name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{children}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Parent.children}} is a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ReverseManyToOneDescriptor}} instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager
class built by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{create\_forward\_many\_to\_many\_manager()}} defined below.

\end{fulllineitems}

\label{\detokenize{payments:module-payments.urls}}\label{\detokenize{payments:payments-urls-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!payments.urls@\spxentry{payments.urls}}\index{payments.urls@\spxentry{payments.urls}!module@\spxentry{module}}

\subsubsection{payments.views module}
\label{\detokenize{payments:module-payments.views}}\label{\detokenize{payments:payments-views-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!payments.views@\spxentry{payments.views}}\index{payments.views@\spxentry{payments.views}!module@\spxentry{module}}
Handles all activities associated with payments that talk to users.

This module handles all of the functions that interact directly with
a user. i.e. they generally accept a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Request}} and return an
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{HttpResponse}}.
See also {\hyperref[\detokenize{payments:module-payments.core}]{\emph{Payments Core}}}. This handles the other side of the interactions.
They both work together.
\begin{description}
\item[{Key Points:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Payments is a service module, it is requested to do things on behalf of
another module and does not know why it is doing them.

\item {} 
Payments are often not real time, for manual payments, the user will
be taken to another screen that interacts directly with Stripe, and for
automatic top up payments, the top up may fail and require user input.

\item {} 
The asynchronous nature of payments makes it more complex than many of
the Cobalt modules so the documentation needs to be of a higher standard.
See \sphinxhref{./payments\_overview.html}{Payments Overview} for more details.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\index{settlement() (in module payments.views)@\spxentry{settlement()}\spxextra{in module payments.views}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{payments:payments.views.settlement}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{payments.views.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{settlement}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{request}}}{}~\begin{description}
\item[{process payments to organisations. This is expected to be a monthly}] \leavevmode
activity.

\end{description}

At certain points in time an administrator will clear out the balances of
the organisations accounts and transfer actual money to them through the
banking system. This is not currently possible to do electronically so this
is a manual process.

The administrator should use this list to match with the bank transactions and
then confirm through this view that the payments have been made.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{request}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{HTTPRequest}}) \textendash{} standard request object

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
HTTPResponse

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{stripe\_autotopup\_confirm() (in module payments.views)@\spxentry{stripe\_autotopup\_confirm()}\spxextra{in module payments.views}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{payments:payments.views.stripe_autotopup_confirm}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{payments.views.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{stripe\_autotopup\_confirm}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{request}}}{}
User has been told by Stripe that auto top up went through.

This is called by the web page after Stripe confirms that auto top up is approved.
Because this originates from the client we do not trust it, but we do move
the status to Pending unless it is already Confirmed (timing issues).

For manual payments we update the transaction, but for auto top up there is
no transaction so we record this on the User object.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{request}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{HTTPRequest}}) \textendash{} stasndard request object

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
Nothing.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

Switch off auto top up

This is called by the web page when a user submits new card details to
Stripe. This is the latest point that we can turn it off in case the
user aborts the change.

calls Stripe to register a customer.

Creates a new customer entry with Stripe and sets this member’s
stripe\_customer\_id to match the customer created. Also sets the

\index{stripe\_pending() (in module payments.views)@\spxentry{stripe\_pending()}\spxextra{in module payments.views}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{payments:payments.views.stripe_pending}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{payments.views.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{stripe\_pending}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{request}}}{}
Shows any pending stripe transactions.

Stripe transactions should never really be in a pending state unless
there is a problem. They go from intent to success usually. The only time
they will sit in pending is if Stripe is slow to talk to us or there is an
error.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{request}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{HTTPRequest}}) \textendash{} standard request object

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
HTTPResponse

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

Role Based Access Control Core

This handles the core functions for role based security for Cobalt.

See \sphinxhref{./rbac\_overview.html}{RBAC Overview} for more details.

\index{rbac\_user\_has\_role\_exact() (in module rbac.core)@\spxentry{rbac\_user\_has\_role\_exact()}\spxextra{in module rbac.core}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{rbac:rbac.core.rbac_user_has_role_exact}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{rbac.core.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{rbac\_user\_has\_role\_exact}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{member}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{role}}}{}
check if a user has an exact role

This is called by rbac\_user\_has\_role to check exact roles. The process
for checking an exact role is always the same. rbac\_user\_has\_role has
the logic to put this together at a higher level and to use defaults
in order to work out if the combination of rules allows a user to do
something. This function only checks at the most specific level.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{member}} ({\hyperref[\detokenize{accounts:accounts.models.User}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{User}}}}}) \textendash{} standard user object

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{role}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} role to check

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
“Allow”, “Block”, or None for no match

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
string

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{rbac\_user\_is\_group\_admin() (in module rbac.core)@\spxentry{rbac\_user\_is\_group\_admin()}\spxextra{in module rbac.core}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{rbac:rbac.core.rbac_user_is_group_admin}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{rbac.core.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{rbac\_user\_is\_group\_admin}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{member}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{group}}}{}
check if a user has admin rights to a group based upon their rights
in the tree. Note \sphinxhyphen{} they also need admin rights to the objects if they are
intending to change the group. This only checks for the ability to change
group membership or delete the group.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{member}} ({\hyperref[\detokenize{accounts:accounts.models.User}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{User}}}}}) \textendash{} standard user object

\item {}

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
bool

\end{description}\end{quote}

\index{rbac\_user\_role\_list() (in module rbac.core)@\spxentry{rbac\_user\_role\_list()}\spxextra{in module rbac.core}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{rbac:rbac.core.rbac_user_role_list}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{rbac.core.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{rbac\_user\_role\_list}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{user}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{app}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{model}}}{}
return list of roles a user has for part of the tree.

This takes in a user and and app/model combination and returns the list of
model\_ids and actions that a user can perform. For example, if you provide:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{app} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{forums}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{n}{model} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{forum}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

This could return:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{23}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{edit}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{23}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{delete}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{55}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{edit}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Only returns things with “Allow” so only works for Block default models.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{rbacgrouprole\_set (rbac.models.RBACGroup attribute)@\spxentry{rbacgrouprole\_set}\spxextra{rbac.models.RBACGroup attribute}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{rbac:rbac.models.RBACGroup.rbacgrouprole_set}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{rbacgrouprole\_set}}}
Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a
many\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}one relation.

In the example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{Child}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{Model}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{parent} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{ForeignKey}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{Parent}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{related\PYGZus{}name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{children}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Parent.children}} is a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ReverseManyToOneDescriptor}} instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager
class built by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{create\_forward\_many\_to\_many\_manager()}} defined below.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{RBACModelDefault (class in rbac.models)@\spxentry{RBACModelDefault}\spxextra{class in rbac.models}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{rbac:rbac.models.RBACModelDefault}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{rbac.models.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{RBACModelDefault}}}{\emph{\DUrole{o}{*}\DUrole{n}{args}}, \emph{\DUrole{o}{**}\DUrole{n}{kwargs}}}{}
Bases: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{django.db.models.base.Model}}

Default behaviour for a model. Some models (e.g. forums.forum) need a
default of allowing users access unless explicitly blocked. Other models
(e.g. organisations.Organisation) need a default behaviour of blocking unless
explicitly allowed.
